PreCR™ Repair MixRepair damaged DNA prior to PCR, microarrays or other technologies.The PreCR Repair Mix is an enzyme cocktail formulated to repair damaged template DNA prior to its use in the polymerase chain reaction (PCR), microarrays or other DNA technologies. This product comes with easy-to-use protocols and does not damage template DNA.DNA is susceptible to many types of damage resulting from exposure to a variety of chemical or environmental reagents, manipulation or simply aging, which prevent the further manipulation of DNA. The PreCR Repair Mix is a blend of recombinant proteins designed to repair damaged template DNA prior to its use in the polymerase chain reaction (PCR), microarrays or other DNA technologies. PreCR is active on a broad range of DNA damage, including those that block PCR (e.g. apurinic/apyrimidinic sites, thymine dimers, nicks and gaps) and those that are mutagenic (e.g. deaminated cytosine and 8-oxo-guanine). In addition, it will remove a variety of moieties from the 3´ end of DNA leaving a hydroxyl group. However the PreCR Repair Mix cannot repair fragmentation or protein-DNA crosslinks.








 
			PreCR ResultsThis gel illustrates repair of different types of DNA damage with the PreCR Repair Mix. The gel shows trial ampliﬁcations from damaged DNA that was either not treated (-) or treated (+) with the PreCR Repair Mix. Type of DNA damage is shown. Note: heat treated DNA is incubated at 99°C for 3 minutes. Marker M is the 2-log DNA Ladder (NEB #N3200). 




PreCR FeaturesEasy-to-use protocols. Amplification can be done directly on the repair reaction, or, if the polymerase being used is not active in ThermoPol Buffer, a sequential reaction protocol is provided. Does not harm template DNACan be used in conjunction with any thermophilic DNA Polymerase.A typical reaction involves a 15-20 minute incubation at 37°C with the supplied components. In some cases, to achieve maximum amplicon yield optimization of the PreCR reaction may be required. This involves varying the amount of template and incubation temperature. Template concentration does not appear to be a limiting factor in this reaction. Each PreCR reaction can repair anywhere from 0.01 ng to 1 µg of damaged DNA.
